>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Turner" <chris@l...> wrote:
>
>1. Why is it that if I create a network with 10 input nodes and 1 
>output nodes, when I use the newwork viewer application is show 
>  
>
>the network as haveing 11 input nodes?
>  
>
Philip got it. There is always one bias input node + however many you 
define for your experiment, and it is always the first node.

>2. I've created an experiment where most test require a simple 
>network in order to get the right answer.  However, a few of the 
>tests require a more complex solution.  What seems to be happening 
>is that the searching process quickly finds the simple network but 
>which achieves about 94% of the fitness but never finds a network 
>that fits the complete solution.  I think a solution should be 
>possible as the inputs are logically created.
>
Can you explain the experiment a bit more, this might help us gauge 
whether a solution should or could be found.

>  I think the more 
>specialised species are being wiped-out before they get the change 
>to evolve properly.  What changes to my network parameters can I 
>make to increase the change of more complex networks?
>  
>
The default species drop-off age is 200. What this means is, if the max 
observed fitness in a species' hasn;t improved for 200 generations then 
the species is culled. I think that's what you're after.

>
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
>
>Chris,
>
>How many generations have you run your experiment?  Sometimes it can 
>take a while to build up the necessary structure to jump 
>from "almost perfect" to "perfect."  That is, it may take hundreds 
>of generations even.  
>
>It is also possible that you have your speciation parameters set up 
>in a way that doesn't let new species develop.  Unfortunately, I 
>don't know exactly how SharpNEAT allocates these parameters (such as 
>the coefficients of the compatibility equations and the 
>compatibility threshold).
>
They are pretty much as defined by standard NEAT. So that's a node, 
connection and weight delta co-efficient. The compatibilty threshold 
starts out at fixed value and is dynamically adjusted to maintain the 
number of species between a upper and lower limits. So generally 
speaking everything balances out by itself after a few gens. For 
non-trivial tasks I do now tend to use a population of 1000 and species 
min/ax thresholds of 40 & 50 respectively. The default settings in 
SharpNEAT are 150 genomes and 6/10 species.

Colin.
